section.title: Deploying a Windows installation packageLE_windows_package
section.para: To enroll Windows servers, you must deploy an installation package. You can also deploy an installation package for Windows desktops and laptops, instead of letting your users enroll these devices themselves.
When you use an installation package to enroll a device, the device is assigned to the default group automatically.
If a server belongs in a different group, you must transfer it manually. Servers are shared resources and are never assigned directly to users.
If a client device belongs to a user, you must transfer it to that user manually.

step.para: Go to Settings > Windows Installation Package, and then select the package type:

listitem.para: Client. A client package is intended for desktops and laptops, where maximum protection is the highest priority.
Server. A server package is intended for servers, which require high performance. The server package does not include intrusion prevention or the firewall.

step.para: Click or tap Download to fetch a helper file, which then retrieves the installation files and places a shortcut to their location on your desktop. The folder name is Symantec .
Go to the actual folder location, and select either the .cmd file or the .msi and .mst files, depending on how you want to install the package.

procedure.title: Installing the protection client directly on the device

step.para: Put the package on a network share, USB device, or other share mechanism.
On the device, run SCS_setup.cmd. This command automatically includes the information that the client needs to communicate with your environment.

procedure.title: Installing the protection client by pushing an Active Directory GPO

step.para: Create your Group Policy Object (GPO) in the usual way.
In addition to the SCS-ESD.msi file, you also need SCS-ESD.mst. The .mst file includes the tokens that must be passed to connect the protection client to Symantec Security Cloud.
You must also use the install at logon option.
